title: Lena Dunham is matching donations to Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Lena Dunham is matching donations to Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center Lena Dunham's latest mission: Drive donations toward Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center. Post to Facebook Lena Dunham is matching donations to Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center Lena Dunham's latest mission: Drive donations toward Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center. Check out this story on Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/2lzZ1He Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 2 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Lena Dunham is matching donations to Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center Detroit Free Press 1:21 p.m. ET Feb. 23, 2017 Lena Dunham arrives at the Glamour Women of the Year Awards on Nov. 14 at NeueHouse Hollywood in Los Angeles. (Photo: Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP) 18 CONNECT 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Lena Dunham's latest mission: Drive donations toward Detroit's Ruth Ellis Center. 
The actress best known for her role in HBO's "Girls" has pledged to match all donations up to $50,000 in support of the Highland Park-based Ruth Ellis Center, a youth social services agency which supports "the needs of runaway, homeless and at-risk LGBTQ youth." 
"Let's fight hate & ignorance with love for trans teens, who are already facing steep odds and who need our support to grow and THRIVE," Dunham tweeted to her 5.3 million followers. 
She's asking anyone who donates to tweet at her a donation receipt (so she can match). I'm matching all donations up to 50k to the Ruth Ellis Center @REC_detroit cc @allycoalition @jackantonoff Tweet me your donation receipt! — Lena Dunham (@lenadunham) February 23, 2017 Challenge your friends! Challenge this administration ✊️ Let's do this, bebes! #protecttranskids — Lena Dunham (@lenadunham) February 23, 2017 
The Ruth Ellis Center, also known as the REC, was incorporated in 1999. It is named after Ruth Ellis, who lived in Detroit from 1938 until her death in 2000 and "opened her home to the community on the weekends as a safe space from the 1940s through the 1960s, a time when African-American gay men and lesbians had few social venues," according to the website . 
You can donate here and check out the Ruth Ellis Center website for more. 
Be sure that you follow the Detroit Free Press on Twitter ( @freep ) and Instagram and like us on on Facebook . 18 CONNECT 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE
